unnormalised: Someone asked me about tax law in India, and honestly, it's a rabbit hole. I’ll try to simplify. My experience with it started back in 2018, after my father retired. He received a hefty sum, and we were clueless about what to do with it tax-wise. He’d always handled the finances, and now it was on me.
normalised: Someone asked me about tax law in India, and honestly, it's a rabbit hole. I'll try to simplify. My experience with it started back in two thousand and eighteen, after my father retired. He received a hefty sum, and we were clueless about what to do with it tax-wise. He'd always handled the finances, and now it was on me.

unnormalised: The first thing I learned was about filing ITR (Income Tax Returns). I had to understand the various sections, like 80C for investments up to ₹150,000, which dad was thankfully already utilizing a bit through his PPF account. We also looked at 80D for medical insurance premiums and realised we could claim a deduction there too, given his age. My CA (Chartered Accountant) friend, Vishal, mentioned something about Sec 54EC bonds to save on capital gains tax from the retirement benefits. It sounded complex but crucial.
normalised: The first thing I learned was about filing I-T-R (Income Tax Returns). I had to understand the various sections, like eighty C for investments up to rupee one hundred and fifty thousand, which dad was thankfully already utilizing a bit through his P-P-F account. We also looked at eighty D for medical insurance premiums and realised we could claim a deduction there too, given his age. My C-A (Chartered Accountant) friend, Vishal, mentioned something about Section fifty four E-C bonds to save on capital gains tax from the retirement benefits. It sounded complex but crucial.

unnormalised: Then came the GST (Goods and Services Tax) part. A relative runs a small textile business in Surat. He was constantly complaining about the complexities of GST returns, specifically GSTR-3B and GSTR-1. He mentioned something about an amendment to Section 16(2)(c) of the CGST Act making it even tougher to claim input tax credit. Honestly, it was all Greek to me, but it highlighted how intricate tax law can be for businesses, especially SMEs.
normalised: Then came the G-S-T (Goods and Services Tax) part. A relative runs a small textile business in Surat. He was constantly complaining about the complexities of G-S-T returns, specifically G-S-T-R-three B and G-S-T-R-one. He mentioned something about an amendment to Section sixteen (two) (c) of the C-G-S-T Act making it even tougher to claim input tax credit. Honestly, it was all Greek to me, but it highlighted how intricate tax law can be for businesses, especially S-M-E-s.

unnormalised: My biggest headache was understanding tax on property. We were planning to buy a flat in Mumbai, and the stamp duty and registration charges were a shock. Vishal explained about Section 24(b) of the Income Tax Act, which allows deduction for interest paid on housing loans. He also pointed out that if we sold a property later, we’d have to pay capital gains tax unless we reinvested the proceeds under Section 54. The value of the flat we were looking at was approx. Rs 1.5Cr.
normalised: My biggest headache was understanding tax on property. We were planning to buy a flat in Mumbai, and the stamp duty and registration charges were a shock. Vishal explained about Section twenty four (b) of the Income Tax Act, which allows deduction for interest paid on housing loans. He also pointed out that if we sold a property later, we’d have to pay capital gains tax unless we reinvested the proceeds under Section fifty four. The value of the flat we were looking at was approximately rupees one point five crore.

unnormalised: So, yeah, tax law in India is a maze. Get a good CA, understand the basics, and don't be afraid to ask questions. And always, *always* file your returns on time. The last date is usually 31/07, unless extended. Trust me, avoiding penalties is worth it!
normalised: So, yeah, tax law in India is a maze. Get a good C-A, understand the basics, and don't be afraid to ask questions. And always, *always* file your returns on time. The last date is usually thirty first july, unless extended. Trust me, avoiding penalties is worth it!
